Posts.Content: Jun 4, 2010 05:29AM TNgolfer wrote: JudyAnnW I read your post and want you to know that we all have other things going on in our lives...not just the breast cancer.  And we have probably all, at one time or another, thought "why bother" as well.  I, too, had too many things on my plate (platter) to deal with.  I signed up for a clinical study on breast cancer and depression and it turned out to be the best thing I did.  Just looking at your signature line, your bc seems to have been caught early and your prognosis should be good.  Life is worth living....it will be hard work to find the joy and make lemonade out of these lemons, but you can do it.  Talk to one of your doctors and have them recommend a psychologist or someone that you can talk to 1:1.  I never took any antidepressants; I found that exercise actually works just as well (there have been studies that verify that).  Sit down and take an assessment of how you spend your days.  Take out the things that are unpleasant and not rewarding.  Replace them with things that YOU truly want to do.  It can be a sport, a hobby, lunch with a friend once a week, a girls night, reading a book once a week, watching a favorite movie, etc.  Eat healthier, put daily exercise in your routine.  Talk a walk daily (bring a camera).  The bc dx can be depressing itself, but add all the other stresses, it's a large load. I am making the changes I need to make to eliminate the stress in my life (that may even mean a separation in my marriage, but it is about me.  I am going to do what I need to do to make my life peaceful.  You can do it, too.  The doctor who is heading up the clinical study that I was in actually wrote a book on the topic.  PM me if you want the info, or if you need anything else. You will be in my thoughts and prayers.  To "smell the roses" you first have to go find them! Marianne

Posts.Content: Mar 25, 2010 02:48PM TNgolfer wrote: To all those struggling with this decision.  You are the only ones who can make the decision.  You can read post after post from those that did one or the other.  Ultimately you will have to decide.  It is an agonizing "no-going-back" decision.  It has to be a decision that YOU are comfortable with.  I personally met with several women; some who had a bilat MX and some who had a unilateral Mx; some with reconstruction and some without.   You have to determine what your personal goal is.  My goal was to be cancer free, have the same range of motion as before, and to be "comfortable" in my own skin -- whatever that was. You can review percentages until your head spins....but you will never know if you are in that 2% or 98%.  It doesn't matter.  You have to make a decision that you won't regret.  Trust that you will.  I was just as scared and bewildered, and then I just knew what was right for me.  YOU WILL TOO! Praying for wisdom for you!

Posts.Content: Mar 2, 2010 01:18PM TNgolfer wrote: Paradise flower, I have read your post and the one thing that stands out to me is that you say your breast is dimpling.  My right nipple was also dimpling and starting to invert.  Mammograms and sonograms showed nothing.  Also had 2 benign breast biopsy's.....go see a breast surgeon.  I saw one and she knew something wasn't right, so she did an excisional biopsy.  Dx invasive lobular carcinoma.  Lobular breast cancer is a sneaky little thing and usually doesn't show up on a mammogram and if it does it has been there a long time and is usually much bigger.   I don't know about all the other pain and symptoms you are having, but my advice is see a breast surgeon!

Posts.Content: Mar 9, 2010 09:27PM TNgolfer wrote: texas girl, It does, indeed, take a few months for a cancerous cell to grow.  But like you I had an indentation; the nipple was starting to invert (or turn).  After two benign biopsy's (one done by the hospital who did a sonogram and thought they saw something) and the 2nd done by a qualified breast surgeon (it was sonogram-guided).  She told me we could wait, but she was concerned.  Nipples don't indent or change for no reason!  She did a hook-wire guided excision (lumpectomy) and it was indeed invasive lobular carcinoma.  I also don't know how anyone can tell you that something doesn't "feel" like cancer.  This cancer did not show up on 2 mammograms and the first two biopsies were benign!  You are wise to get another opinion.  I agree with Nancy, time is on your side.

Posts.Content: Mar 1, 2010 08:36PM TNgolfer wrote: I am also awaiting results of Oncotype Dx assay.  I have done extensive research and will definitely not do chemo if Oncotype is 18 or lower, and it won't necessarily be a given if I am in the "grey area".  With tumors that are ER+, chemo is pretty ineffective.  There is a lot of research out there. I would encourage all to find as much info as they can.  Estrogen is a hormone and hormone therapy makes more sense than chemotherapy for er+ tumors.
